About UniTracks

Find out about UniTracks and how it is helping shape the way people engage within the digital world

Helping people become better digital citizens

The goal of UniTracks is to help deal with the digital skills gaps within the UK. A 2019 study conducted by Lloyds Bank found that 11.9 million people do not have the essential digital skills needed for day-to-day life meaning they are unable to turn on a device or open an app. The study also found that 53% of employees do not have the digital skills needed for work. These figures highlight the importance of teaching digital citizenship and part of UniTracks aims is to help educate university students about core digital skills. This will help reduce the digitals skills gap and will prepare students for the digital workplace environments.

UniTracks Mission

What people think about Digital Citizenship

Take a look at what other people have to say about Digital Citizenship

Richard Culatta

CEO of ISTE

Digital citizenship is about much more than online safety — or a long list of don’ts. It’s also about the do’s that help create thoughtful, empathetic digital citizens who can wrestle with the important ethical questions at the intersection of technology and humanity.

Germany Kent

American broadcast journalist

If you are on social media, and you are not learning, not laughing, not being inspired or not networking, then you are using it wrong. What you post online speaks volume about who you really are. Post with intention and repost with caution. Use social media for good.

Mike Ribble

Digital Citizenship Expert

Students use more devices at home and in the classroom. But, are they prepared to be good digital citizens? Just as you teach your students the rules of society, it is imperative that you teach the rules of the digital world, and how to be safe and responsible online.

Jill Felty

Technology School Teacher

Good citizenship in person needs to flow over into good citizenship online. It has a lot of the same principles; respect, being kind and meeting expectations. Kids were born with technology and know how to do things we don’t. But they don’t think about the consequences.
